        "first_name": "Elliott",
        "last_name": "Alexander",
        "username": "escottalexander",
        "message": "I don't know anyhting about the python package so I can't say but what I will say is that due to the nature of the way flashbots works there may be some time delay that cannot be predicted. Here is why: You are signing your transactions assuming a gas price of X then you submit your bundle and if the gas price has moved a little (X+1) then your transactions will only be included when the gas price goes back down. That depends on network demand. Might take a minute, might take days! No way to predict when gas prices will spike suddenly.",
        "media_type": null,
        "media_path": null,
        "reply_to": null
    },
    {
        "id": 61,
        "message_id": 61,
        "date": "2024-07-10 14:52:57",
        "sender_id": 1345091703,
        "first_name": "Elliott",
        "last_name": "Alexander",
        "username": "escottalexander",
        "message": "We build in a little 10% buffer to help curb this and make it so that most of the time your bundle is included within a few minutes but there is a lot out of our control.",
        "media_type": null,
        "media_path": null,
        "reply_to": null
    },

        "username": "escottalexander",
        "message": "The reason why Flashbots is successful in recovering assets is because the whole operation of sending funds in => sending assets out happens without the hacker knowing it is happening until after it has occurred. If you use flashbots to just send ETH to the wallet then once that transaction is included the hacker can see that that wallet has ETH and can then make a new transaction to sweep them.",

        "first_name": "Elliott",
        "last_name": "Alexander",
        "username": "escottalexander",
        "message": "Ok. You will need to find someone why has built a frontrunning script. This is what the hacker is doing with your wallet. When you send a transaction, they have a bot that is watching the mempool and it sends a transaction with higher gas than your original transaction. Hence their transaction is mined first and your is then invalid. There are scripts that attempt to \"race\" the hackers bot by increasing the gas fee and if it senses that the hacker has sent a higher gas fee tx then it makes one that is even higher. Basically you are racing to the most gas expended. They will likely use all your gas to get your a little that is left. You can write in to this channel to see if someone has built this in the past and would guide you through it: ğŸ—Scaffold-ETH - general developer chat.",

    {
        "id": 322,
        "message_id": 324,

        "last_name": null,
        "username": "BugsFinder0x",
        "message": "Sorry guys i don't understand what \"recovery\" does it mean.\nIf someone get my private key, will transfer my money to another wallet.\nI can't recover that money.\nAm I wrong?",
        "media_type": null,
        "media_path": null,
        "reply_to": null
    },
    {
        "id": 323,
        "message_id": 325,
        "date": "2024-08-26 14:09:14",
        "sender_id": 5676830229,
        "first_name": null,
        "last_name": null,
        "username": null,
        "message": "You are wrong, kind of!",
        "media_type": null,
        "media_path": null,
        "reply_to": 324
    },
    {
        "id": 324,
        "message_id": 326,
        "date": "2024-08-26 14:09:59",
        "sender_id": 1345091703,
        "first_name": "Elliott",
        "last_name": "Alexander",
        "username": "escottalexander",
        "message": "You are correct. There is no way to recover funds that have been sent out of your wallet. What the app can help with is when your wallet gets hacked the hacker usually sets up a sweeper bot that will sweep any funds you send to it so that means you won't have enough gas in your wallet for recovering an ENS or other nft that the hacker left in the wallet. Hacked Wallet Recovery helps by using Flashbots to send the gas to your wallet and the recovery transaction (moving the nft out of the wallet) without the sweeper bot seeing the fund go to your wallet until after the recover has been completed.",
        "media_type": null,
        "media_path": null,
        "reply_to": 324
    },

    {
        "id": 374,
        "message_id": 376,
        "date": "2024-09-13 15:18:11",
        "sender_id": 1199422694,
        "first_name": "aieioiueaeuioieia",
        "last_name": null,
        "username": null,
        "message": "so how is it possible for law enforcement to get to the funds with special equiptment, or is this also bogus?",

    },
    {
        "id": 375,
        "message_id": 377,
        "date": "2024-09-13 15:20:29",
        "sender_id": 1345091703,
        "first_name": "Elliott",
        "last_name": "Alexander",
        "username": "escottalexander",
        "message": "No, so there are technically ways to recover funds but it requires hacking the hacker to get their keys or using centralized exchanges to flag the funds in the event the hacker moves them to an exchange. So there are ways but I think anyone claiming to do it for $650 is trying to scam people.",
        "media_type": null,
        "media_path": null,
        "reply_to": null
    },
    {
        "id": 376,
        "message_id": 378,
        "date": "2024-09-13 15:21:21",
        "sender_id": 1345091703,
        "first_name": "Elliott",
        "last_name": "Alexander",
        "username": "escottalexander",
        "message": "There is no 100% sure method for recovering the funds. It all depends on how susceptible the hacker is.",

        "media_path": null,
        "reply_to": null
    },
    {
        "id": 377,

        "last_name": null,

        "first_name": "Elliott",
        "last_name": "Alexander",
        "username": "escottalexander",
        "message": "Seal_911 is a group of excellent hackers who can help recover funds through a combination of the above methods I mentioned. They have a lot of skills and influence that enables them to help people with this problem.",

        "media_path": null,

        "message_id": 381,
        "date": "2024-09-13 15:25:40",
        "sender_id": 1345091703,
        "first_name": "Elliott",
        "last_name": "Alexander",
        "username": "escottalexander",
        "message": "Yes. I was speaking in generalities. It is a question of the things you mentioned + the hackers vulnerability. If the hacker is moving the funds to exchanges or across L2s then they are more vulnerable. If they are keeping their keys on a aws server then they are vulnerable. But there are definitely ways where they could keep the funds unreachable. Most likely they will want to move them to a centralized exchange and cash out but that is risky for them.",

        "sender_id": 6723167125,
        "first_name": "Greg",
        "last_name": "F",
        "username": "Gregf87444",
        "message": "cause its a family comp meaning im not the only person in the house using the comp, and if the comp gets infected, first choice is to always reformat the whole thing and reinstall the OS, however it not always convenient until whatever backup needs to get done by each family member before proceeding to erase everything",
        "media_type": null,

    },
    {
        "id": 507,
        "message_id": 510,
        "date": "2024-11-22 19:19:37",
        "sender_id": 1345091703,
        "first_name": "Elliott",
        "last_name": "Alexander",
        "username": "escottalexander",
        "message": "The problem with this is it doesn't matter if you remove a malicious script from your computer. If the script has run once and your wallet has been exposed then that wallet is forever exposed and rendered useless.\n\nSince it is a family computer and you can't guarantee that a family member won't accidentally click a malicious link and run something on your computer I would recommend only keeping small quantities of funds on the wallet on this computer. You should set up a multisig for any larger amounts you would hate to lose. Assuming you have a smart phone, you could also just use wallet connect from your mobile device instead of relying on the computer to be secure.",
        "media_type": null,
        "media_path": null,
        "reply_to": null
    },
    {
        "id": 508,
        "message_id": 511,
        "date": "2024-11-22 19:22:06",
        "sender_id": 1345091703,
        "first_name": "Elliott",
        "last_name": "Alexander",
        "username": "escottalexander",
        "message": "One thing that a lot of people don't realize is that malicious scripts can be found in seemingly innocuous files like .docx and .pdf. Always be careful about what files you download and open.",
        "media_type": null,
        "media_path": null,
        "reply_to": null
    },

        "first_name": "Elliott",
        "last_name": "Alexander",
        "username": "escottalexander",
        "message": "Some hacker has your private key for that account and is running a sweeper bot to snatch any funds you send to it.",

    {

        "message_id": 519,
        "date": "2024-11-22 19:37:25",
        "sender_id": 1345091703,
        "first_name": "Elliott",
        "last_name": "Alexander",
        "username": "escottalexander",
        "message": "The solution is to use Hacked Wallet Recovery to\n1. fund the hacked walet\n2. move the erc20 out of the hacked wallet\nall in one action so that the hacker can't see the funds until they have already been used to recover the erc20.",
        "media_type": null,
        "media_path": null,
        "reply_to": null
    },
    {
        "id": 517,
        "message_id": 520,
        "date": "2024-11-22 19:45:41",
        "sender_id": 1345091703,
        "first_name": "Elliott",
        "last_name": "Alexander",
        "username": "escottalexander",
        "message": "The way HWR works is by using a private mempool called Flashbots. It makes it so that all of your transactions get executed in the same bundle so it isn't possible for the hacker to add a transaction that sends the funds to their own address.",
        "media_type": null,
        "media_path": null,
        "reply_to": null
    },

# Hacked Wallet Recovery 
## User friendly UI for building transaction bundles for Flashbots
Use the tool here: [HackedWalletRecovery.com](https://hackedwalletrecovery.com/)

Note: This can not be used to recover assets that are already sent to a hackers address, it can only help you send transactions from your hacked wallet on Mainnet.

Features:
- Displays a list of any assets sitting in the hacked wallet
- Provides ways to construct custom transactions using a contract ABI 
- You can paste in a raw transaction (super useful for airdrop claims!)
- Automatically handles gas estimations and the original funding transaction
- Attempts to automatically add the Flashbots RPC and guides the user through adding it manually if it fails

## How to use Hacked Wallet Recovery

### 1. Start by providing the hacked wallet address.

  Input the address of your hacked wallet and click "Discover". On the next screen you will see any ERC20, ERC721 and ERC1155 assets that are still in the wallet.

### 2. Select assets.

  If you don't see your asset or you need to do a specialized transaction click on "Add Manually". See [#manually-adding-assets] for detailed instructions. Once you have selected the assets(or the manually constructed transactions you just built) __in the order you want them to execute__ you can click "Continue".

  Note: If it fails to go to the next step it likely means there is a revert happening in your selected transactions. Make sure they are selected in the order you want them to execute and verify they are constructed properly.

### 3. Review the transactions

  Glance at the transactions on the list. Confirm they are in the order you anticipate and none are missing. Once you have confirmed click "Start Signing".

### 4. Connect safe wallet

  It will prompt you to connect a wallet that has funds to cover gas fees and for funding the hacked wallet so it can send transactions.

### 5. Switch to the Hacked Wallet Recovery RPC

  The app will prompt you to add a special RPC network that will allow you to prepare your transactions without sending them to the Mainnet mempool. This is a crucial step because if you continue without changing the RPC your funds will get swept by the hacker as soon as they are sent to your hacked wallet. Double check that you have switched to the new RPC and then continue.

### 6. Sign the funding transaction

  It will prompt you to sign a transaction that sends the necessary funds to the hacked wallet so the hacked wallet has enough funds to execute the transactions you selected earlier.

  Note: Even though you are signing transactions with your wallet in this step and the next these transactions are not actually executed on Mainnet until the final step where we submit the bundle. We are just creating the bundle right now.

### 7. Switch to your hacked wallet

  __This wallet must be connected to the same RPC we added earlier.__ Connect the wallet that was hacked in preparation for signing the transactions you selected earlier.

### 8. Sign the recovery transactions

  You will now be prompted to sign each transaction you selected earlier. Make sure you use the site suggested gas price and ignore any gas adjustment suggestions from your wallet provider as this may make the cost of the transactions greater than the funding transaction that you created at the beginning.

### 9. Wait for the transaction bundle to be included in a block

  The app will now try to submit your transactions as a bundle in every block until it gets accepted by a Flashbots relayer. Be patient as it may take a few minutes.

__YOU DID IT! RECOVERY COMPLETE!__

## Manually adding assets
You can manually add assets in four ways:
### 1. Add a ERC20, ERC721 or ERC1155 by it's details

  Select the "Basic" tab and click "Add" under the asset type you wish to add. Follow the prompts to add the contract address, token id(s) etc.

### 2. Create a custom transaction using the contract address and ABI for the method you are calling

  Click on "Custom". Enter the contract address you are going to call with your transaction. Now enter the function signature(e.g. `transfer(address,uint)` for a typical ERC20 send). It should show inputs for each parameter that your function requires. It can be helpful to play around with the contract on [Etherscan](https://etherscan.io/) in order to find the function signature if you aren't familiar with this process. Often times airdrop claims require you to provide a "proof" as one of the claim parameters. Sometimes they make this information easy for the public to find but often you have to [dig through the network requests](https://developer.chrome.com/docs/devtools/network) on the claim site to find this information. Read this note on [airdrop claims!](#airdrop-claims)

### 3. Paste in a raw transaction

  This may be the easiest for airdrop claims. Go to the claim site and go through the normal process for claiming. When the site sends the transaction to your wallet for signing - *don't sign* (you probably can't anyway for lack of funds). Instead of signing, copy the raw transaction and paste it in this box. Read this note on [airdrop claims!](#airdrop-claims)

### 4. ABI Ninja

  The [ABI Ninja](https://abi.ninja) method is great for helping you see what functions are available to call on the contract address you paste in. Paste in an address and then click "Load Contract". Next you should click the hamburger menu to see the read and write functions. Select the write function you want to use and then close the menu by either clicking outside of the sidebar or at very top of the menu there is an X icon. You should see the function with inputs for each parameter required. Once you have entered the parameters you can click "Send" and it should return you to the asset selection view in Hacked Wallet Recovery with your new transaction selected. If you encounter errors while in ABI Ninja it may be giving you helpful feedback on a mistake you made when adding a parameter.

  ABI Ninja has a limitation in that you cannot create a transaction that reverts. For instance, you can use it for creating a transaction to claim an airdrop but if you try to create a transaction for moving the airdropped tokens it will fail because your hacked account does not actually have the tokens yet, you have only created a transaction that *will* move the tokens when you execute all the transactions as a bundle. You can still use the other methods for creating a transaction to move the tokens.

### Airdrop claims
If you use option 2 or 3 for claiming an airdrop, make sure you also create a transaction that moves the token to a safe wallet. It would be sad to go through all this trouble just to watch your tokens get swept because you merely claimed them *to* your hacked wallet and forgot to move them out of your hacked wallet. You should be able to use the "Basic" tab (option 1) with the token contract address to move them out of your wallet. If that fails then you can use the "Custom" tab. *Just don't forget to do it!*

        "message": "I don't know anyhting about the python package so I can't say but what I will say is that due to the nat

ure of the way flashbots works there may be some time delay that cannot be predicted. Here is why: You are signing your transactions assuming a gas price of X then you submit your bundle and if the gas price has moved a little (X+1) then your transactions will only be included when the gas price goes back down. That depends on network demand. Might take a minute, might take days! No way to predict when gas prices will spike suddenly.",
        "media_type": null,
        "media_path": null,
        "reply_to": null
    },
    {
        "id": 61,
        "message_id": 61,
        "date": "2024-07-10 14:52:57",
        "sender_id": 1345091703,
        "first_name": "Elliott",
        "last_name": "Alexander",
        "username": "escottalexander",
        "message": "We build in a little 10% buffer to help curb this and make it so that most of the time your bundle is included within a few minutes but there is a lot out of our control.",
        "media_type": null,
        "media_path": n

ull,
        "reply_to": null

        "first_name": "Elliott",
        "last_name": "Alexander",
        "username": "escottalexander",
        "message": "Ok. You will need to find someone why has built a frontrunning script. This is what the hacker is doing with your wallet. When you send a transaction, they have a bot that is watching the mempool and it sends a transaction with higher gas than your original transaction. Hence

their transaction is mined first and your is then invalid. There are scripts that attempt to \"race\" the hackers bot by increasing the gas fee and if it senses that the hacker has sent a higher gas fee tx then it makes one that is even higher. Basically you are racing to the most gas expended. They will likely use all your gas to get your a little that is left. You can write in to this channel to see if someone has built this in the past and would guide you through it: ğŸ—Scaffold-ETH - general developer chat.",

        "first_name": "Elliott",
        "last_name": "Alexander",
        "username": "escottalexander",
        "message": "You are correct. There is no way to recover funds that have been sent out of your wallet. What the app can help with is when your wallet gets hacked the hacker usually sets up a sweeper bot that will sweep any funds you send to it so that means you won't have enough gas in your wallet for recovering an ENS or other nft th

at the hacker left in the wallet. Hacked Wallet Recovery helps by using Flashbots to send the gas to your wallet and the recovery transaction (moving the nft out of the wallet) without the sweeper bot seeing the fund go to your wallet until after the recover has been completed.",

        "media_path": null,
        "reply_to": 324

        "first_name": "Greg",
        "last_name": "F",
        "username": "Gregf87444",
        "message": "cause its a family comp meaning im not the only person in the house using the comp, and if the comp gets infected, first choice is to always reformat the whole thing and reinstall the OS, however it not always convenient until whatever backup needs to get done by each family member before proceedin

g to erase everything",

    {
        "id": 507,
        "message_id": 510,
        "date": "2024-11-22 19:19:37",
        "sender_id": 1345091703,
        "first_name": "Elliott",
        "last_name": "Alexander",
        "username": "escottalexander",
        "message": "The problem with this is it doesn't matter if you remove a malicious script from your computer. If the script has run once and your wallet has been exposed then that wallet is forever exposed and rendered useless.\n\nSince it is a family computer and you can't guarantee that a family member won't accidentally click a malicious link and run something on your computer I would recommend only keeping small quantities of funds on the wallet on this computer. You should set up a multisig for any larger amounts you would hate to lose. Assuming you have a smart phone, you could also just use wallet connect from your mobile device instead

of relying on the computer to be secure.",
        "media_type": null,
        "media_path": null,
        "reply_to": null
    },
    {
        "id": 508,
        "message_id": 511,
        "date": "2024-11-22 19:22:06",
        "sender_id": 1345091703,
        "first_name": "Elliott",
        "last_name": "Alexander",
        "username": "escottalexander",
        "message": "One thing that a lot of people don't realize is that malicious scripts can be found in seemingly innocuous files like .docx and .pdf. Always be careful about what files you download and open.",
        "media_type": null,
        "media_path": null,
        "reply_to": null
    },

        "first_name": "Elliott",
        "last_name": "Alexander",
        "username": "escottalexander",
        "message": "The solution is to use Hacked Wallet Recovery to\n1. fund the hacked walet\n2. move the erc20 out of the hacked wallet\nall in one action so that the hacker ca

n't see the funds until they have already been used to recover the erc20.",

        "first_name": "Elliott",
        "last_name": "Alexander",
        "username": "escottalexander",
        "message": "The way HWR works is by using a private mempool called Flashbots. It makes it so that all of your transactions get executed in the same bundle so it isn't possible for the hacker to add a transaction that sends the funds to their own address.",

# Hacked Wallet Recovery 
## User friendly UI for building transaction bundles for Flashbots
Use the tool here: [HackedWalletRecovery.com](https://hackedwalletrecovery.com/)

Note: This can not be used to recover assets that are already sent to a hackers address, it can only help you send transactions from your hacked wallet on Mainnet.

Features:
- Displays a list of any assets sitting in the hacked wallet
- Provides ways to construct custom transactions using a contract ABI 
- You can paste in a raw transaction (super useful for airdrop claims!)
- Automatically handles gas estimations and the original funding transaction
- Attempts to automatically add the Flashbots RPC and guides the user through adding it manually if it fails

## How to use Hacked Wallet Recovery

### 1. Start by providing the hacked wallet address.

  Input the address of your hacked wallet and click "Discover". On the next screen you will see any ERC20, ERC721 and ERC1155 assets that are still in the wallet.

###

2. Select assets.

  If you don't see your asset or you need to do a specialized transaction click on "Add Manually". See [#manually-adding-assets] for detailed instructions. Once you have selected the assets(or the manually constructed transactions you just built) __in the order you want them to execute__ you can click "Continue".

  Note: If it fails to go to the next step it likely means there is a revert happening in your selected transactions. Make sure they are selected in the order you want them to execute and verify they are constructed properly.

### 3. Review the transactions

  Glance at the transactions on the list. Confirm they are in the order you anticipate and none are missing. Once you have confirmed click "Start Signing".

### 4. Connect safe wallet

  It will prompt you to connect a wallet that has funds to cover gas fees and for funding the hacked wallet so it can send transactions.

### 5. Switch to the Hacked Wallet Recovery RPC

  The app will prompt you to add

a special RPC network that will allow you to prepare your transactions without sending them to the Mainnet mempool. This is a crucial step because if you continue without changing the RPC your funds will get swept by the hacker as soon as they are sent to your hacked wallet. Double check that you have switched to the new RPC and then continue.

### 6. Sign the funding transaction

  It will prompt you to sign a transaction that sends the necessary funds to the hacked wallet so the hacked wallet has enough funds to execute the transactions you selected earlier.

  Note: Even though you are signing transactions with your wallet in this step and the next these transactions are not actually executed on Mainnet until the final step where we submit the bundle. We are just creating the bundle right now.

### 7. Switch to your hacked wallet

  __This wallet must be connected to the same RPC we added earlier.__ Connect the wallet that was hacked in preparation for signing the transactions you s

elected earlier.

### 8. Sign the recovery transactions

  You will now be prompted to sign each transaction you selected earlier. Make sure you use the site suggested gas price and ignore any gas adjustment suggestions from your wallet provider as this may make the cost of the transactions greater than the funding transaction that you created at the beginning.

### 9. Wait for the transaction bundle to be included in a block

  The app will now try to submit your transactions as a bundle in every block until it gets accepted by a Flashbots relayer. Be patient as it may take a few minutes.

__YOU DID IT! RECOVERY COMPLETE!__

## Manually adding assets
You can manually add assets in four ways:
### 1. Add a ERC20, ERC721 or ERC1155 by it's details

  Select the "Basic" tab and click "Add" under the asset type you wish to add. Follow the prompts to add the contract address, token id(s) etc.

### 2. Create a custom transaction using the contract address and ABI for the method you are calli

ng

  Click on "Custom". Enter the contract address you are going to call with your transaction. Now enter the function signature(e.g. `transfer(address,uint)` for a typical ERC20 send). It should show inputs for each parameter that your function requires. It can be helpful to play around with the contract on [Etherscan](https://etherscan.io/) in order to find the function signature if you aren't familiar with this process. Often times airdrop claims require you to provide a "proof" as one of the claim parameters. Sometimes they make this information easy for the public to find but often you have to [dig through the network requests](https://developer.chrome.com/docs/devtools/network) on the claim site to find this information. Read this note on [airdrop claims!](#airdrop-claims)

### 3. Paste in a raw transaction

  This may be the easiest for airdrop claims. Go to the claim site and go through the normal process for claiming. When the site sends the transaction to your wallet for sig

ning - *don't sign* (you probably can't anyway for lack of funds). Instead of signing, copy the raw transaction and paste it in this box. Read this note on [airdrop claims!](#airdrop-claims)

### 4. ABI Ninja

  The [ABI Ninja](https://abi.ninja) method is great for helping you see what functions are available to call on the contract address you paste in. Paste in an address and then click "Load Contract". Next you should click the hamburger menu to see the read and write functions. Select the write function you want to use and then close the menu by either clicking outside of the sidebar or at very top of the menu there is an X icon. You should see the function with inputs for each parameter required. Once you have entered the parameters you can click "Send" and it should return you to the asset selection view in Hacked Wallet Recovery with your new transaction selected. If you encounter errors while in ABI Ninja it may be giving you helpful feedback on a mistake you made when adding

a parameter.

  ABI Ninja has a limitation in that you cannot create a transaction that reverts. For instance, you can use it for creating a transaction to claim an airdrop but if you try to create a transaction for moving the airdropped tokens it will fail because your hacked account does not actually have the tokens yet, you have only created a transaction that *will* move the tokens when you execute all the transactions as a bundle. You can still use the other methods for creating a transaction to move the tokens.

### Airdrop claims
If you use option 2 or 3 for claiming an airdrop, make sure you also create a transaction that moves the token to a safe wallet. It would be sad to go through all this trouble just to watch your tokens get swept because you merely claimed them *to* your hacked wallet and forgot to move them out of your hacked wallet. You should be able to use the "Basic" tab (option 1) with the token contract address to move them out of your wallet. If that fails then y
ou can use the "Custom" tab. *Just don't forget to do it!*
